Lady? madam? boy; madam, Aspero ▪ but whist, I have the conceit, 'twas excellent in my lady, and i applaud it, suppose my lady and her prisoner had an intent of private business in the next room; was it not better in her to blind me, than I should as gentlemen ushers (Cases so standing) have
blinded myself? again, i applaud her, and adore my stars that made me rather a blind then a seeing doorkeeper: shall I interrupt them? no: madam? they have not done yet, sure they have not: what have we here? A base viol! though i cannot tickle the minikin within, I'll (Though it be some what base) give them a song without, and the name of the ditty shall be;
The gentleman ushers voluntary.

lg.l: Peace, peace, peace, make no noise,
End, end, end your idle toys,
Kiss, kiss and part, though not for hate for pity,
Ha done, ha' done, ha' done, for I ha' done my ditty.

div.p: And if you have not done now too, let me be as base as my fiddle, if I rouse you not: madam for shame, what do you mean to make of me, how? sfoot what have you made of me already? all gone? Jailor?

sp.speaker: Assistance
sp.l: How now? who calls?

sp.speaker: Hort.
sp.l: Why saucy knave 'tis J.

sp.speaker: Assistance
sp.l: You, what you?

sp.speaker: Hort.
sp.p: A single v, I came in double, but I thank them, they are gone out, and left me here a single. —

sp.speaker: Assistance
sp.l: Fool, and so I leave you.

sp.speaker: Hort.
sp.l: Knave, I am Hortensio, I charge thee let me out.

sp.speaker: Assistance
sp.p: Fool, you lie, you are Aspero, and I have charge to keep you in.

sp.speaker: Hort.
sp.l: From whom?

sp.speaker: Assistance
sp.l: From my lord Hortensio.

sp.speaker: Hort.
sp.p: 'Sfoot knave i tell thee I am he, and thou wilt not believe me, trust thine eyes, come in and see.

sp.speaker: Assistance
sp.p: 'Twill not serve your turn, i like a whole skin better than a pinked one: content yourself tonight , and in the morning I'll tell you more.

sp.speaker: Hort.
sp.l: Where's my lady, send her hither,

sp.speaker: Assistance
sp.p: She's busy with my lord Hortensio, but if you have any use for a woman, I'll send you one of the laundresses: fare you well sir, be content, you shall want nothing of any thing you have.

sp.speaker: Hort.
sp.p: Hortensio gone outland my lady busy with Hortensio ▪ I am gulled, palpably gulled: whilst I like a block stood courting the post, Aspero is in my apparel escapded: villains, traitors, open the door, the duke's abused, his daughter's fled: I proclaim ye all traitors that hinder me in the pursuit.

sp.speaker: Assistance
sp.p: O for a reasonable audience to applaud this scene of merriment: I'll go call my lady and my lord Hortensio.

sp.speaker: Hort.
sp.p: Blindman's buff? I have buffed it fairly, and mine own gullery grieves me not half so much as the Duke's displeasure, jailer, not a word? jailer, there's no way to please a knave but fair words, and gold: honest kind jailer, here's gold for thee: do but take pity upon me, a miserable coney-catched courtier: not? neither fair nor foul? thou art a degree worse than a woman; what shall I do? I can compare my fortune and my unfortunate self to nothing so fitly as my base here, we suffer every fool to play upon us for their pleasure: and indeed 'twas the intent of our creator that made fiddles and servitors to nothing but to be played upon, and played upon we shall be, till our heart strings crack, and then they either cast us aside or hang us up, as worthy no other employment; well, if I can work my means, of escape, so: if not, I must lie by it.

div.head: Actus Qvintus.
div.stage: Enter Octavio, Francisco, Hippolito Flaminco ▪ etc.

lg.l: My daughter fled? and with Hortensio,
It bears no formal shape of likelihood,
her eagle spirit soared too proud a pitch,
To seize so base a prey; let privy search
Look through the city's bosom till they find her:

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: Has not Anthony's son
Sent them by some base practice to their death?

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.l: His breasts too full of honour; trusty Julio?
What weighty business draws thee from thy charge?

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Came not the cause afore me? the proud Mantuans
Basely revolt, deposed me from the seat
And chair of regentship, sending in quest
Of proud Anthonio their late-banished Duke,
Him if they find or Aspero his sonEnter assist.
They'll reinstall him in the regiment ▪

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.p: Him let them seek in the vast shades of death, as for his son.

sp.speaker: Assistance
sp.p: He's sure enough my lord, he was a mad knave when he came in, but i think, I have made a tame fool of him by this time: for 'a has neither had bread nor water these four and forty hours.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.l: More villain thou.

sp.speaker: Assistance
sp.p: My lord, Hortensio was the villain, he left such command with me, he's the wheel that turns about, and I a country Jack must strike when I am commanded.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.l: Although my foe, he's honourably tempered,
Yet armed against my life go ▪ call him forth,
Guard in my safety with a ring of steel,
And mark how proudly he'll demean revenge.

div.stage: Enter assistance and Hortensio bareheaded with his crowd,

sp.speaker: Assistance
sp.l: Goblins, spirits, furies, fairies, the prison is haunted.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.l: With a knave is't not?

sp.speaker: Assistance
sp.p: Yes, and an old fool my lord, in the likeness of Hortensio.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.l: Villain where's Aspero.

sp.speaker: Assistance
sp.p: I know not my lord: I let him in and my lady to laugh at him, and it seems, he consented to treason, and let him out in his apparel.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.p: They consented together to cozen me, for taking delight (As my betters may do) in a foolish pastime called blindman's buff, they stole away my gown, escaped the prison, and left me in fool's paradise, where, what song I have played, my viol can witness, they made me a little better than a bawd my lord.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: In act:

sp.speaker: Hort.
sp.p: Not merely in act: sed cogitation, et id satis est ut inquit Suetonius.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.l: Is he escaped ▪ and Florimell with him?
Hortensio thy head shall answer it.

sp.speaker: Hort.
sp.p: I pray let my tongue be my heads attorney, and plead my excuse.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.l: Urge no excuse, away with him to prison.

sp.speaker: Assistance
sp.l: It shall be done my lord.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.p: Nay you sir too, shall taste of the same sauce, away with both,

sp.speaker: Flamineo.
sp.l: Come my sons,
Let's levy present arms 'gainst Mantua.
Being scarce come home we must abroad again,
The common good's a careful prince's pain.

div.stage: Enter Anthonio, Lucida, Hermia and lords.

sp.speaker: Anth.
sp.l: You that in all my banished pilgrimage,
Would never alienate your natural loves,
But in desire to see me reinstalled,
Have thrust out proud Octavio's substitute,
And seated me in ancient dignity,
I am yours, and ready at your best dispose.

sp.speaker: Lord
sp.l: Your own, my liege, we like inferior lights
Take life from your reflection, for like stars
Unto the sun, are counsellors to Kings ▪
he feeds their orbs with fire, and their shine
Contend to make his glory more divine.
And such are we to great Anthonio.

sp.speaker: Anth.
sp.l: The veins and arteries of Anthonio
Through which the blood of greatness flows in us.
Our life, and cause efficient of our state,
And these our pretty partners in exile.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.l: We ha' yet performed but the least part of duty,
Your reinstalment: it rests, that with our blood,
We keep out innovative violence.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: You new-create me, and breath second life
Into my dying bosom, knew my son
Of this unlooked-for fortune, but ill fate
Has played the traitor, and given up his life
To coward treason.

div.stage: Enter Aspero and Florimell with their pages.

sp.speaker: Asp.
sp.p: Udsfoot what offence have I committed against the state, that these iron-handed plebeians so applaud me for?

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: 'Tis a sign they love you ▪

sp.speaker: Asp.
sp.p: I had rather thy should hate me, it makes me suspect my bosom, for they love none, but the masters of factions, treasons, and innovations.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Then you do not love the commons.

sp.speaker: Asp.
sp.p: Yes, as wise men do their flattering wives, only for show: the popular voice is like a cry of bawling hounds, and they get the foot of a fantastic and popular-affecting statesman, they never leave him, till they have chased him into disgrace, and then, like hounds, are at a loss, and with their loss, see, I have found my father, safety attend you.

sp.speaker: Anth.
sp.l: Welcome thou hope of Mantua and of us,
We now are honours new beginners boy,
And may we better thrive then heretofore.

sp.speaker: Asp.
sp.p: Never doubt it father, I have attractive stuff that will draw customers.

sp.speaker: Anth.
sp.l: What lady's that.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: One that has played the part of a constable, brought you home a runaway.

sp.speaker: Asp.
sp.p: A friend of mine father, but daughter to your arch-enemy.

sp.speaker: Anth.
sp.l: Octauio's daughter?

sp.speaker: Asp.
sp.p: Yes faith, you are out with the father, and I'll see if I can fall in with the daughter.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: And am I not a good child to leave my father's love at six and seven, and hazard my honour upon your son's naked promise, and your hopeful acceptance.

sp.speaker: Asp.
sp.l: She has followed me through much danger.

sp.speaker: Anth.
sp.l: The better welcome, I love her for't.

sp.speaker: Asp.
sp.p: Like her and you please, I'd have nobody love her but myself.

sp.speaker: Anth.
sp.l: And lady, though your father be our foe,
The virtuous love betwixt our son and you,
May ne'ertheless retain his sympathy.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Shall ne'ertheless retain his sympathy,
Anthonio know I am love's resolute,
Confirmed and grounded in affection:
I loved your son, not for he was a prince,
But one no better than his present fortunes,
I'll love him still, since first I loved him so,
Let father, friends, and all the world say no.

sp.speaker: Asp.
sp.p: There's mettle father, how can we choose but get cocking children, when father and mother too are both of the game.

sp.speaker: Messenger
sp.l: To arms my lord, Octavio comes in arms
To give a proud assault unto the city.

sp.speaker: Asp.
sp.l: Proud his assault, as proud be our resist,
Vie shot for shot, and stake down life for life,
Our breast's as bold as theirs, our blood as deep,
All that we'll lose, or this our gettings keep.

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.l: Come brother, talk not of devouring war,
Say messenger, comes not Octauio's sons?

sp.speaker: Messenger
sp.l: They do, as proudly as the morning sun
beating the azured pavement of the heaven.

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.l: Then fear not father, my sister and myself,
Will be your champions and defend the city.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Why ladies, have you such large interest in our brothers.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: Princess, we have, within there: reach our shields,
When beauty fights, the god of battle yields. Exeunt.

div.stage: Enter Anthonio, Aspero, Florimell, two pages lords and messenger above.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: They offer parley, let me answer them.
Brothers, how now? who made you soldiers?
Faith e'en my father as he made you lovers ▪
What? hath he changed your shepherd's hooks to swords?
Of amoradoes made you armed knights?
O seld-seen metamorphosis! I have known
Soldiers turn lovers, but for amorous lovers
To reassume their valour, 'tis a change,
Like winter-thunder, and a thing as strange.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: Our sister prisoner?

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: Tell me Florimell,
Dost thou live there enforced, or of freewill?

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: Free will, brothers, mine own free will, all free in Mantua, here's free will i'faith, speak am I not a freewoman?

sp.speaker: Page
sp.p: As if you had served for't, any man may set up under her copy without a protection.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: I wag? are you there too?

sp.speaker: Page
sp.p: Yes faith my lord, my lady has had my attendance to a hair.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: You lie boy.

sp.speaker: Page
sp.l: If not mine, somebody's else: there's one has done —

sp.speaker: Asp.
sp.l: What have I done sirrah?

sp.speaker: Page
sp.p: Nay nothing, but what my lady was very well content with.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: Why sister, shame you not to set your love
On one, that is our father's enemy.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Shame? not a whit: but come, your wench's brothers,
I make no question, I have won my wager:
Are they as fair as I?

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: Leave that to trial.
Aspero make surrender of our sister.

sp.speaker: Asp.
sp.l: And have her in quiet possession? what do you think me.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: We think thee a proud villain and our foe.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: By heaven, they're villains all that think him so,

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: Why do you love him.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: I should curse myself
If I should hate him:

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: Bring the ladders forth,
Bravely assault to separate their lives,
As they are sealing the walls, the ladies come forth.

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.l: Stand proud Francisco.

sp.speaker: Page
sp.l: Sand! O excellent word in a woman!

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Hold Hippolito.

sp.speaker: Page
sp.l: Hold! up with that word, and 'tis as good as the other.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: What nymph or goddess in my Hermia's shape,
Stands to debar my entrance to the town:

sp.speaker: Page
sp.l: Madam, I wonder they enter not.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Why boy it seems they dare not,

sp.speaker: Page
sp.l: O cowards and have two such fair breaches already,

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: Immortal Pallas that art more divine,
In my love's beauty that thou clothest thee in,
With draw thyself, and give our fury limits.

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.l: I will, but first Francisco take my shield.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: And mine as challenge to a single combat,

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.l: Read the conditions and return your answers.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: Well done i'faith wenches, oh that the old graybeard my father were here, I'd have about with him as I am honourable.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: What's here!
A shepherd wooing of a country maid,
As she sits angling by a river's side,
By them an aged man making a net!
The motto ▪ sic! this emblems moral is,
The former love I had with Lucida,
And this hope tells me that's fair ▪ Lucida.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: Brother, my shield the like presents to me,
But holds far more familiar reference,
Here doth the amorous shepherd kiss the nymph;
Which she with a chaste blush consents unto:
And see, a gloomy man, clad like a pilgrim
Comes in, and separates their sweet delights:
The motto, sic! I so my father came,
And banished me from beauteous Hermia,
And this hope tells me is fair Hermia.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: The more I look, the more methinks 'tis she.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: The more I think the more I find 'tis she.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: What should I think to prove it is not she?

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Look, think, find, prove, do what you can,
These are the wenches that you courted then:
Then honey bees lay by your smarting stings,
And buzz sweet love into your lady's ears,
Tell them of kisses, and such pretty things,
These drumming dubadubs love's pleasure fears.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: O heaven, o fortune, and most happy stars,
Do I find love, where I expected wars?

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: I that but now was all for war and death,
Am made all love, war's humour's out of breath.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.p: How, my son's love the daughters of my foe! it cannot be,

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Then question them yourself.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.l: Why how now sons, is this your worth in arms.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: Why are we not in arms father.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: Yes, and in such arms as no coward, but would venture life to march in.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.l: Then boys, you love the daughters of Anthonio.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: We liked them first.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: Wel●ep● the liking still.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.l: And you will love them.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Father in faith they will.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.p: Ay, run away are you there? whom has your ladyship got to your husband?

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: One that I stumbled on at blindman buff, a proper man, a man every inch of him: and you would say so, and you knew but as much as I — mean to know ere I have done with him ▪

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.l: Is he not son unto Anthonio?

sp.speaker: Asp.
sp.l: Great Duke I am, and prostrate on my knee,
I beg a peace, which if your spleen deny,
I proudly stand where erst I mildly kneeled,
And East down bold defiance from these walls.

sp.speaker: Oct.
sp.l: No more your loves make my proud heart ashamed,
Your consort's sweet, and I'll not be a mean
To make it jar: what my sons like shall stand,
By my consent, allowed and perfected;
All hate is banished, and revenge lies dead.

sp.speaker: Asp.
sp.l: Then stead of spears, let Hymen's torches flame
With hallowed incense, and the god of spright,
Swell up your veins with amorous delight:
And so that up our single comedy,
〈◊〉 Plautus phrase: si places, plaudite.

div.head: Textual Notes
div.p: The textual notes below aim at making textual corrections readable in their immediate context and facilitating access to the source text. A five-dit number preceded by 'A' or 'B' represents an EEBO-TCP filenumber. A notation like "6-b-2890" means "look for EEBO page image 6 of that text, word 289 on the right side of the double-page image." That reference is followed by the corrupt reading. A black dot stands for an unidentified letter, a black square for an unidentified punctuation mark, a diamond for a missing word, and the ellipsis for a short span of undefined length. The corrected reading is displayed as a kewyord in context.
